data.title: Goodbye, Farewell and Amen (1983)
data.meta_description: This feature-length film is the last episode of the long-running television series M*A*S*H, which follows an army surgical team during the Korean War. After years of serving together, the close-knit unit is about to be disbanded. Capt. "Hawkeye" Pierce (Alan Alda) is recovering from a nervous breakdown, while his friends, like easygoing Capt. B.J. Hunnicut (Mike Farrell) and uptight Maj. Charles Winchester (David Ogden Stiers), deal with the impending change in their own ways.
data.text:
“I know how tough it is for you to say goodbye, so I’ll say it. Maybe you’re right, maybe we will see each other again, but just in case we don’t, I want you to know how much you’ve meant to me. I’ll never be able to shake you”.

40 years ago today, history was made. The finale to M*A*S*H aired, setting the record for most viewed telecast in history. 106 million people tuned in for the finale (peaking at 125 million in the last 6 minutes of the telecast), which was almost half the U.S. population in 1983. It’s a record that’s hasn’t even come close to being beaten by another scripted show (only the Super Bowl has since…

"Go. What are you waiting for?"

"I - I ... just thought there might be something we wanted to say to each other before I left."

mr. alda tell me what you meant, textually, to be going on in this scene if not a failed love confession

I’ve been trying to write this for about 10 minutes now, but attempting to articulate just how much this show and these characters have come to mean to me is impossible.

There are episodes of this show that are more daring and experimental than any film I’ve ever seen. “Dreams” comes to mind almost immediately, as a truly haunting exploration of the profound mark that the war has left on these people, and it’s absolutely beautiful.

And that’s what MASH is to me, it’s an exploration of the impact of war. Throughout the series we see these characters face death and destruction every single day, and no matter how much they try and distract themselves with jokes and booze, there…
